Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Undergraduate Research Experiences in Big Data Security and Privacy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at California State Polytechnic University, Pomona. This REU Site will host a diverse group of undergraduate students who will spend their summer working on cutting-edge big data security research problems in genomic data privacy, secure multiparty cloud computation, and hybrid data center security. This REU Site provides students with the opportunities to explore the challenges of big data security and privacy using state-of-the art tools and testbeds. Security and privacy issues are magnified by big data, with the diversity of data sources and formats as well as large-scale cloud infrastructures needed to support big data applications. As a result, traditional security mechanisms are not adequate and new mechanisms and policies related to the security and privacy of big data are needed. The research is led by an interdisciplinary group faculty actively engaged in cybersecurity research. The site will provide mentoring and other professional development opportunities that should impact the future academic and professional careers of the students. The site plans to attract talented undergraduate students from across the nation, particularly focusing on recruiting Hispanic and women students, groups traditionally under-represented in the computing fields.

The research projects in this REU Site address new big data security and privacy problems, such as genomic data privacy protection, accelerated encryption algorithms for genomic data in acquisition, privacy preserving big data mining, secure multiparty computation on clouds, security compliance measurement in hybrid data centers, and data governance in migration among clouds. While these topics can be closely interconnected, they address security and privacy issues in different phases of the big data life cycle. The projects will use a new High Performance Computing Cluster and a student run campus data center to provide research that in both theory and application in an emerging area of research.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site in Big Data Security and Privacy at California State Polytechnic University, Pomona (Cal Poly Pomona, CPP) ran successfully from 2018-2021. Each year this REU Site hosted a diverse group of undergraduate students who spent 10 weeks in summer working on cutting-edge big data security research problems in genomic data privacy, secure multiparty cloud computation, machine learning security and hybrid data center security. The students were mentored by an interdisciplinary group of faculties active in cybersecurity research and worked closely with them in an immersive research environment. In the program, students delivered two poster presentations, i.e., the midterm presentation at Southern California CISE REU Symposium (2018, 2019) with peers and faculty across REU sites, and the final on-campus presentation at the CPP Creative Activities & Research Symposium. We also provided numerous professional development and social activities of various forms to students, such as invited speakers series and field trips to NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory. After summer, the site provided students with continuous mentoring support for paper publication and graduate school application. The success of this REU site has been reflected in recruitment, research publications, student outcomes and student satisfaction. 

In Summer 2020, we successfully implemented our REU site virtually online due to COVID-19 Pandemic. 

Recruitment

Our REU site remains fully committed to recruiting motivated undergraduate students with varied gender, socio-economic, and racial/ethnic backgrounds and who are interested in big data security but who have not had the opportunities to explore the cutting-edge research opportunities and careers. In the past three years, our REU site has attracted a diverse pool of 346 applications in three years (33.3% female, 66.7% male; 14% Hispanic, 11% African American, 31% White, 35% Asian, 9% Others). Among the 24 participants in the last three years, 67% were from non-research institutions. Among the participants who belong to underrepresented student groups, we hosted six female students, three Hispanic, one African American, one Native Pacific Islander student, and three students with documented disability.

Student Publications

The CPP Big Data Security and Privacy REU site has been successful in formal writing skill training and paper publications. We have published seven papers to date (all with REU students as the first authors) in peer-reviewed conferences; three more have been submitted and are in review. Our students presented their REU research works at the 2019 AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence, the 2019 ACM SIGKDD Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining (KDD) 2019 Workshop, the 2018 and 2019 IEEE Big Data Conferences, the 2020 ACM Practice and Experience in Advanced Research Computing (PEARC), and the 2020 Conference on Computer Vison and Pattern Recognition (CVPR) Workshop.

Student Outcomes

In the past three years, 11 of our REU students graduated from their undergraduate programs; of those, four (4) are enrolled in masters or doctoral (Ph.D.) programs. Among the 7 graduated students who started working, one student is now employed with a permanent position at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, and another is working in cybersecurity area at a federal government agency. One of REU student received the prestigious Goldwater Scholarship in 2020 and another student received NSF Graduate Research Fellowship award in 2021. Most REU participants who have not graduated from undergraduate program are also indicating their interest in pursuing graduate school. In addition, our REU students have received internship offers from well-known industry companies such as Microsoft and Amazon.

Student Perceptions

Our external program evaluator Dr. Miriam Fultz conducted pre-program survey, midterm focus group interview with REU students, and post-program survey in each year, to collect students’ feedback for improvement. Overall, our REU site obtained an average median score of 4.39/5 in the satisfaction level of the program. Self-reported ratings from our students indicate constant growth of students in our four student learning outcomes: 1) improved preparedness towards research, 2) enhanced key research-related skills, 3) strengthened professional skills, and 4) greater intention for graduate studies in big data and cybersecurity.

Broader Impact

As Cal Poly Pomona is a top-rated Hispanic serving institution, this project offered opportunities to a diverse group of students including under-represented minorities in CISE majors. The project prepared the nation’s new generations of big data security researchers through research and professional development activities that nurture students’ improved preparedness towards research, enhanced key research-related skills, strengthened professional skills, and greater intention for graduate studies in big data and cybersecurity. Finally, our site contributed to our Nation’s efforts to strengthen its critical information infrastructures and to improve the current pedagogical practices in the area of big data security and privacy.
